title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
Former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin was convicted of murdering George Floyd in a jury decision that US president Joe Biden said had the potential to be “a moment of significant change”.

Floyd's death last year set off worldwide protests against racial injustice and Chauvin's trial became one of the most closely watched US court cases in years.

Chauvin, 45, was found guilty on all three charges: second-degree and third-degree murder and second-degree manslaughter. The second-degree murder count, the most serious charge, carries a prison sentence of up to 40 years.

In George Floyd Square, the intersection where Floyd died, and outside the courthouse the mood was celebratory after the decision was announced — a rare instance of a police murder conviction.

The guilty verdict for Chauvin — and the speed with which the jury returned it — will probably be remembered as a high point of black Americans' long battle for racial justice, writes Taylor Nicole Rogers.

Coronavirus digest

  • The US government can use its ownership of a crucial vaccine patent to push companies to share their expertise with other manufacturers and boost global access to coronavirus jabs, according to a top scientific official.

  • Roche, the Swiss pharmaceutical company, reported a 55 per cent jump in diagnostic sales in the first quarter thanks to strong demand for Covid-19 tests, including a new product to track virus variants. 

  • The Japanese city of Osaka has asked the national government to declare a new state of emergency, with Tokyo and Hyogo prefectures set to follow.

  • The UK has launched a drive to “supercharge” the search for home-based Covid-19 drug treatments. British households have suffered a bigger income shock during the crisis than their French and German counterparts.

  • An FT analysis of data from five countries — each facing very different scenarios — finds that rates of infections, hospitalisation and death have traced a lower path among the older, most vaccinated age groups than among the younger, who are least likely to have received the jab.

Follow the latest news on our live blog and sign up for our Coronavirus Business Update email newsletter.

In the news

Xi to join Biden's climate summit despite tensions China's president Xi Jinping will attend a US-led climate summit this week, bolstering hopes of co-operation between the world's two largest greenhouse gas emitters despite heated tensions between Beijing and Washington.

Super League crumbles as all 6 English clubs pull out The decision of England's leading football clubs to withdraw from the European Super League came after a day of frantic behind-the-scenes discussions and international condemnation for the project. JPMorgan features as the tin-eared multinational bank trampling on local sensibilities after the breakaway league's collapse, writes our Lex column.

Tesla apologises after Chinese state media attacks Tesla has apologised after being attacked by Chinese state media for its treatment of customers, days after a protest against the company in one of its most important markets. The US carmaker's presence at the Shanghai auto show this week was overshadowed by demonstrators wearing T-shirts alleging Tesla vehicles had “malfunctioning brakes”.

Netflix shares slide after missing subscriber target The streaming giant added only 4m subscribers in the first quarter, a sharp slowdown from the 37m pandemic-driven gains it made last year. Netflix stock has climbed only 2 per cent this year as the US emerges from the pandemic after soaring more than 60 per cent last year. In after-market trading they fell another 10 per cent.

EU facial recognition rules European regulators have proposed strict curbs on the use of facial recognition in public spaces, limiting the technology to a small number of public-interest scenarios, including searches for missing children and policing in terrorism events, according to draft legislation seen by the FT. The Brussels Briefing email, your essential guide to what matters in Europe, is relaunching on Monday. Sign-up here.

  • Popular Chinese video app TikTok is being sued for several billion pounds and accused of illegally collecting personal data from millions of children in the UK and Europe.

Cass Business School to be renamed after statistician Thomas Bayes City, University of London, is to rename its business school after the 18th century statistician, philosopher and Presbyterian minister Thomas Bayes, ending a 20-year association with slavery-tainted Sir John Cass.

HSBC chief vows not to ‘flip-flop' on China strategy Europe's largest bank will not “flip-flop” on strategy every time there is a flare-up in tensions between Beijing and the west, said chief executive Noel Quinn, rebuffing criticism for moving closer to China as it cracks down on Hong Kong.

Russia to pull out of International Space Station in 2025 Dmitry Rogozin, the head of Russia's space programme, said on Wednesday that the country will abandon its section of the International Space Station by the middle of the decade, ending one of the most prominent and long-lasting areas of co-operation between Moscow and Washington.

The day ahead

IPO Shares in software company UiPath will begin trading after the biggest software IPO since Snowflake. The company, which sells software that helps clients automate routine tasks such as reading documents and updating databases, priced its shares at $56 apiece on Tuesday night.

Lina Khan hearing The Senate commerce committee will hold a nomination hearing for Lina Khan, a vocal critic of Big Tech, for the Federal Trade Commission.

Earnings Anthem, NextEra Energy, Verizon, Baker Hughes and Chipotle Mexican Grill report results.

Putin's annual address The Russian president will deliver his State of the Nation address amid growing tensions with Ukraine and a hunger strike by anti-corruption campaigner Alexei Navalny. Half a million Russians have registered online to take part in protests in support of the activist on Wednesday. (CNBC, FT)

Queen Elizabeth's birthday The Queen marks her 95th birthday. The official celebration is on the second Saturday of June. (Telegraph)

What else we're reading

Economic recovery masks dangers of a divided world In essence, the IMF forecasts that advanced economies and China will emerge from the pandemic largely unscathed economically, while emerging and developing countries will suffer a large and long-term hit. But remember that two-thirds of humanity live in the latter, writes Martin Wolf.

CEOs aren't sharing the pain Last year, corporate bosses told us that we were all in it together as they promised to forgo parts of salaries or bonuses amid the pandemic-induced havoc. But the bottom line on CEO pay turned out to be rather different than the headlines suggested, writes Brooke Masters.

Scotland faces life after oil The oil boom shifted Scotland's economic centre of gravity from west to east. It also offered a ticket to soothing voters' concerns that the country could end up free but poorer, outside the union with the UK. As prices slump, can renewable energy replace it?

China's keyboard warriors fight . . . each other Since its inception, the Chinese Communist party has recognised the importance of propaganda. In recent years, its cyber space regulator has championed the need for a “main force” on the internet, which it calls “the main battlefield for public opinion”. But the country's nationalist bloggers sometimes engage in friendly fire.

The new frontiers of hybrid work take shape After more than a year of remote work, the future looks hybrid: a mix of office and home-based working. But it's not straightforward. “Hybrid is a third way. It's incredibly difficult to do,” says one expert at the Boston Consulting Group. 

A cancel culture ‘cleanse' In the febrile world of social-media activism, our professional, private and romantic profiles are routinely combed for controversial content. This is an age in which a bad tweet can get you fired and anyone — from actors to ordinary citizens — can be “cancelled” overnight. Jemima Kelly asks: is a digital clean-up the answer?

Video of the day

China, Russia and the new space race Beijing and Moscow have signed a deal to build a Moon base as they seek to rival the US. Global China editor James Kynge and Moscow bureau chief Henry Foy examine how the partnership might develop and why the two countries have teamed up.
